questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with recurrent episodes of facial swelling, particularly around her lips, along with a history of facial palsy. On examination, she also has a fissured tongue (lingua plicata) as shown below. Based on these clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome

  • Idiopathic disorder marked by a triad of recurrent facial nerve palsy, facial/lip swelling, and a fissured tongue.

 

  • Onset is in childhood or early adolescence.
  • It can be symptomatic of crohn's disease or sarcoidosis.

Treatment:

 

Medical management

 

Steroids:

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice (1 mg/kg/day).
  • Dosage: If reported within 1 week, administer for 5 days and taper off by the 10th day. If paralysis persists, continue the same dose for 10 more days.

 

Surgical Treatment

  • Nerve Decompression: Relieves pressure on nerve fibers, improving microcirculation.

 

Bell's Palsy (Option A): This involves sudden, unilateral facial nerve paralysis but lacks the recurrent swelling and fissured tongue seen in Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome.

 

Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B): Characterized by dry eyes and mouth due to autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands, it doesn't typically present with facial swelling or facial nerve palsy.

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Option D): Caused by varicella-zoster virus reactivation, it presents with facial nerve palsy, ear pain, and vesicular rash in the ear, but not with fissured tongue or lip swelling.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive hearing loss in her right ear with a ringing sensation over the past 8 months. On examination, she has a unilateral sensorineural hearing loss on the right side. An MRI scan of the brain with gadolinium contrast reveals a well-circumscribed, enhancing mass about 4cm in size at the cerebellopontine angle. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surgery

 

Explanation:

The scenario is of acoustic neuroma. Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus and MRI with gadolinium contrast findings points to the diagnosis.

Treatment of choice of acoustic neuroma is surgery

Treatment

Details

Surgery
  • Treatment of choice.
  • The surgical approach depends on the tumor size.

Radiotherapy


 
  • Conventional radiotherapy by external beam is not suitable due to low CNS tolerance to radiation.
  • X-knife or Gamma knife surgery:
    • Form of stereotactic radiotherapy
    • Focuses radiation on the tumor, minimizing the effect on surrounding normal tissue
    • Arrests tumor growth and can reduce size
    • Used for patients who refuse or are contraindicated for surgery, or with residual tumor after surgery.
  • CyberKnife - An improved version

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was diagnosed with Acoustic neuroma. Which among the following cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) V

 

Explanation:

Earliest cranial nerve to be involved is V, followed by VII, X, XI and others.

 

Acoustic Neuroma:

 

Clinical Features
  • Age 40-60, both sexes equally affected
  • Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus
  • Imbalance, facial numbness, dysphagia in later stages

Cranial Nerves Involved
  • V: Earliest to be involved (Option A), Reduced corneal sensitivity, facial numbness
  • VII: Hypoaesthesia, delayed blink reflex, reduced lacrimation
  • X, XI: Dysphagia, hoarseness
  • May involve other cranial nerves as disease progress

Investigations
  • Pure tone audiometry: High-frequency sensorineural loss, roll-over or decay phenomenon seen. (Roll over associated with vestibular symptoms is called as Tulio phenomenon)
  • Speech audiometry: Poor discrimination
  • MRI with gadolinium: Gold standard, ice-cream cone appearance seen.

Vestibular schwannoma - Wikipedia" data-tags="" height="643" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/VAFezU3EBcfDqXek1Ba51738729188.png" width="500" />

Treatment
  • Surgery: Middle cranial fossa, translabyrinthine, suboccipital, combined approach
  • Radiosurgery: Gamma knife, Cyberknife

Differential Diagnosis
  • Meningioma, epidermoid, arachnoid cyst, metastases

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presented with hearing loss, tinnitus and vertigo. MRI showed the finding as shown.



Choose the most likely origin nerve and the cell involved in this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inferior vestibular nerve - Schwann cells

 

Explanation:

Hearing loss accompanied by vestibular symptoms with MRI showing ice-cream cone appearance is suggestive of Acoustic neuroma, better called as Vestibular Schwanomma.

 

Acoustic Neuroma:

Incidence
  • Constitutes 80% of cerebellopontine angle tumors, 10% of all brain tumors

Pathology
  • Benign, slow-growing tumor of the VIIIth cranial nerve; consists of spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei; bilateral in neurofibromatosis
  • Characteristics: Antoni A- hypercellular area, Antoni B- hypocellular area, verocay bodies with nuclear palisading seen.

Verocay bodies - annotated - Schwannoma - Wikipedia" data-tags="" height="375" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/TKkmnPVbPynySVJrXSXx1738728995.png" width="500" />

Origin
  • Arises from Schwann cells of the Inferior vestibular (Option D) > Superior vestibular >> Cochlear division of VIIIth nerve within internal auditory canal

 

Cochlear SNHL

Retrocochlear SNHL

Hair cells are damaged mainly

Lesion is of VIIth nerve or its central connections

Recruitment is present

Recruitment absent

No significant tone decay

Tone decay is significant

SISI is positive

SISI is negative

Bekesy shows no gap between I and C tracing (Type II)

Bekesy shows wide gap between I and C tracings (type III)

Speech discrimination is not highly impaired (SDS) is low) and roll over phenomenon is not present

Speech discrimination is highly impaired (SDS very poor) and roII over phenomenon is present

Subjective feeling of displacusis, hyperacusis or fullness in the ear

No such sensation or feeling

questions.text: Post-parotidectomy, a patient presented with complaints of sweating over the cheek region upon chewing food as shown. Which statement is inappropriate?

choices.text: Abnormal innervation of greater auricular nerve with damaged facial nerve
Tympanic neurectomy is done for treating this
Starch iodide test is helpful in establishing a diagnosis
Interpositional flaps during surgery reduced the risk of this

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abnormal innervation of greater auricular nerve with damaged facial nerve

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Frey’s syndrome.

Fig: Frey’s syndrome

 

Frey’s syndrome:

Cause:

Faulty innervation of parasympathetic fibers of auriculo-temporal nerve (Option A) supplying sweat fibers of face following Parotid surgery.

Clinical features:

gustatory sweating and flushing over angle of mandible

Diagnosis:

Starch Iodide test (Option C)

 

Prevention:

Use of Interpositional flaps like Sternocleidomastoid flap during surgery. (Option D)

Treatment:

Botox injection, Tympanic neurectomy. (Option B)

Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation):

Cause:

Faulty innervation of parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland.

Symptoms:

Unilateral lacrimation during eating

Treatment:

Tympanic neurectomy

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with a 6-week history of swelling of both cheeks as shown, redness of eyes and cough. She reported having difficulty moving the right side of her face. On examination, Angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were elevated. Lymph node biopsy showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heerfordt syndrome

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a subacute variant of Sarcoidosis characterized by Uveo-Parotid fever and facial nerve palsy, known as Heerfordt syndrome.

 

Heerfordt Syndrome:

  • Subacute variant of Sarcoidosis, characterized by anterior uveitis, Parotitis and Facial nerve palsy.
  • ACE (Angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels elevated.
  • Biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas.
  • Treatment: Systemic corticosteroids.

 

Syndromes associated with Facial nerve palsy:

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s Granulomatosis)

(Option C)
  • Autoimmune necrotizing vasculitis.
  • Granulomas in respiratory tracts and kidneys.
  • Facial nerve paralysis with Sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated c-ANCA.
  • Treatment: Cyclophosphamide + steroids.

Lyme Disease

(Option B)
  • Cause: Borrelia burgdorferi, Vector: Hard tick.
  • Flu-like symptoms, erythema migrans, bilateral facial palsy.

                      Fig: Erythema migrans
  • Diagnosis: Serologic testing.
  • Treatment: Doxycycline or amoxicillin, if contra-indicated - Azithromycin.

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome
  • Peripheral facial nerve palsy with erythematous vesicular rash on ear or mouth.

Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome

(Option A)
  • Recurrent alternating facial palsy, furrowed tongue, faciolabial edema.

Moebius Syndrome
  • Congenital agenesis of VI and VII cranial nerve nuclei.
  • Seen with Misoprostol teratogenicity.

questions.text: The Blink Reflex test primarily evaluates the function of which two cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Cranial nerves V and VII

 

Explanation:

Electrodiagnostic tests are useful to differentiate between neurapraxia and degeneration of the nerve and also help to predict the prognosis and indicate time for surgical decompression of the nerve.

 

Different electrodiagnostic tests are:

 

Blink Reflex Test:

  • Purpose: This test evaluates the integrity of both the trigeminal nerve (afferent pathway) and the facial nerve (efferent pathway).
  • It involves stimulating the supraorbital nerve and recording the reflexive blink response in both eyes.
  • Clinical Significance: An absent or delayed response, particularly the R2 component, can indicate damage to the facial nerve or brainstem.

 

Electromyography (EMG):

  • Purpose: Assesses the electrical activity of muscles at rest and during voluntary contraction.
  • Helps to determine the extent of muscle denervation and reinnervation.
  • In normal resting muscle, biphasic or triphasic potentials are seen every 30-50ms.
  • In a denervated muscle, involuntary action potentials called fibrillation potentials appear after 14-21 days.
  • They appear 6-12 weeks prior to clinical evidence of facial function and provide the earliest evidence of recovery

 

Electroneurography (ENoG):

  • Purpose: Measures the compound muscle action potential (CMAP) generated by facial muscles in response to electrical stimulation of the facial nerve.
  • It is used to quantify the degree of facial nerve degeneration.
  • ENoG is most useful between 4-21 days of onset of complete paralysis.

 

Minimum Nerve Excitability Test:

  • The nerve is stimulated at steadily increasing intensity till facial twitch is seen which is compared with the normal side.
  • When the difference between the two sides exceeds 3.5m amp, the test is positive for degeneration.
  • Degeneration of fibres cannot be detected earlier than 48-72 hours.

 

Maximum Stimulation Test(MST):

  • In this test the current level which gives maximum facial movement is determined and compared with the normal side.
  • Reduced or absent response with maximum stimulation indicates degeneration and is followed by incomplete recovery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?

choices.text: They are more common than longitudinal fractures.
Bleeding from the ear is common due to injury to the tegmen and tympanic membrane.
They commonly result in sensorineural hearing loss.
Facial paralysis occurs less frequently and usually has a delayed onset.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) They commonly result in sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Explanation:

Fractures of the temporal bone may be longitudinal, transverse or mixed.

  • Facial palsy is seen more often in transverse fractures.
  • Paralysis is due to intraneural haematoma, compression by bony spicule or transection of nerve.

temporal bone fracture | Radiology Case | Radiopaedia.org" data-tags="" height="530" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/UhM3Z852QQdHOoVoNGhj1738728194.png" width="500" />

Differences in longitudinal and transverse fractures of the temporal bone

 

Longitudinal

Transverse

Frequency

More common (80%)

Less common (20%) (Option A)

Type of injury

Parietal blow

Occipital blow

Fracture line

Runs parallel to the long axis of the petrous pyramid which starts at the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Runs across the petrous which starts at the foramen magnum.

Bleeding from ear

Common, due to injury to tegmen and TM

Absent (Option B)

CSF otorrhoea

Present

Absent

Structures injured

Tegmen, ossicles and TM

Labyrinth, CN VIII

Hearing loss

Conductive

Sensorineural (Option C)

Vertigo

Less often

Severe

Facial paralysis

Less, delayed onset.

Most common, immediate onset. (Option D)

Treatment:

It is important to know whether paralysis was of immediate or delayed onset.

  • Delayed onset paralysis is treated conservatively with prednisolone(1mg/kg/day).
  • Immediate onset paralysis requires surgery in the form of decompression, reanastomosis of cut ends or cable nerve graft.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a painful vesicular rash on his right ear, along with weakness on the same side of his face, making it difficult to close his eye. He also reports hearing loss and vertigo. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome ( Herpes Zoster Oticus):

  • Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with facial nerve palsy, a painful vesicular rash around the external auditory canal and pinna.

\

Fig: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome Ear

  • There may be anaesthesia of the face, giddiness and hearing impairment due to the involvement of 5th and 7th nerves.

Fig: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome Face

Treatment:

Medical management:

  • Steroids:
    • Prednisolone is the drug of choice (1 mg/kg/day).
    • Steroids can be combined with Acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus.
    • Dosage: If reported within 1 week, administer for 5 days and taper off by the 10th day. If paralysis persists, continue the same dose for 10 more days.

 

Surgical Treatment:

  • Nerve Decompression: Relieves pressure on nerve fibers, improving microcirculation.

 

Bell's Palsy (Option A): Involves sudden, unilateral facial nerve paralysis, often without pain or rash. It does not typically include a vesicular rash, hearing loss, or vertigo.

 

Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome (Option B): Characterized by a triad of recurrent facial nerve palsy, facial swelling (especially of the lips), and a fissured tongue. It does not involve vesicular rashes, hearing loss, or vertigo.

 

Acoustic Neuroma (Option D): Benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues. It doesn’t cause facial nerve palsy or a vesicular rash, distinguishing it from Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with weakness in the lower right side of her face. She notes that she can still raise her eyebrows and wrinkle her forehead on both sides. Her emotional expressions seem normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Supranuclear facial nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

The scenario is of a kind of facial palsy in which the forehead and facial expressions are spared, which is supranuclear palsy of the facial nerve

 

Supranuclear palsy of the facial nerve:

  • The upper part of the facial nerve nucleus which innervates the forehead muscles receives fibers from both cerebral hemispheres. Forehead function is preserved in supranuclear lesions due to this bilateral innervation.
  • Emotional movements (e.g., smiling, crying, etc.) are preserved in supranuclear palsies due to the thalamic fibers that the facial nerve nucleus receives.
  • There is weakness on the lower part of her face.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old diabetic male presents to your clinic as shown



Choose the inappropriate statement regarding the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Males and females are equally affected
Most commonly vertical segment is affected

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Most commonly vertical segment is affected

 

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell’s palsy (idiopathic LMN Facial nerve palsy)

Bell’s palsy:

Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset (Option B)
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve is involved. (Option C)
  • Males and females are equally affected. (Option A)

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover (Option D)
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

questions.text: Choose the correct set of facial nerve branch involved and interpretation of a positive test with respect to the image shown below

choices.text: Greater petrosal nerve: >25% unilateral decrease in lacrimation
Greater petrosal nerve: >75% unilateral decrease in lacrimation
Lesser petrosal nerve: >25% unilateral decrease in lacrimation
Lesser petrosal nerve: >75% unilateral decrease in lacrimation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Greater petrosal nerve: >75% unilateral decrease in lacrimation

 

Explanation:

  • Given image shows Schirmer test, a topodiagnostic test used for dry eye disease.

 

  • Topodiagnostic evaluation of facial palsy involves testing the function of individual branches of the facial nerve to assess the site of lesion, but carries no prognostic value.

 

Topodiagnosis of Facial nerve branches:

Test

Nerve Branch

Assessment/Outcome

Schirmer’s Test

Greater (superficial) petrosal nerve
  • A unilateral decrease in tear production (>75%) (Option B) or
  • Bilateral reduction (less than 10 mm in both eyes after 5 minutes).

Stapedial Reflex

Nerve to stapedius muscle
  • Reflex is either present or absent

Electro- gustometry

Chorda tympani
  • The taste threshold is compared between the two sides to detect abnormalities

Salivary Flow Testing

Chorda tympani
  • A 25% reduction in salivary flow is considered abnormal

To assess prognosis following injury, Electrophysiological tests are done as follows,

Electroneuronography (ENoG)
  • Done between 3 days - 3 weeks
  • False positive within <3 days, due to wallerian degeneration
  • Not useful in long-standing paralysis

Electromyography (EMG)
  • Done after 2 weeks
  • Used for testing in long-standing paralysis

questions.text: Nerve that carries taste sensation from the yellow-shaded region of the tongue in the image below arises from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Middle of the vertical segment

 

Explanation:

  • Yellow shaded region represents the anterior two-thirds of the tongue; the taste sensation from that region is carried by the Chorda tympani (Branch of the facial nerve).
  • General sensation of anterior two-third: Lingual nerve (Branch of CN-V)
  • Both taste and general sensation of posterior one-third: Glossopharyngeal nerve

Branches of the facial nerve and its functions:

Branch

Origin

Function

Greater Superficial Petrosal Nerve

Geniculate ganglion
  • Carries secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland, nasal mucosa and palate.
  • Tested by Schirmer’s test

Nerve to Stapedius

At the level of the second genu
  • Supplies the stapedius muscle.
  • Tested by Stapedial reflex.

Chorda Tympani

Middle of the vertical segment

(Option D)
  • Carries secretomotor fibers to submandibular and sublingual glands.
  • Taste sensation from anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Posterior Auricular Nerve

Facial nerve trunk
  • Supplies muscles of the pinna and occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis.
  • Communicates with the auricular branch of the vagus.

Terminal Branches

(Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Mandibular, Cervical)

Within the parotid gland after crossing styloid process
  • Supplies muscles of facial expression.

 

At the level of 1st genu (Option A): Incorrect — this is where the greater petrosal nerve arises, not the chorda tympani.

 

At the level of 2nd genu (Option B): Incorrect — this is a landmark for the nerve to stapedius, not chorda tympani.

 

Middle of the horizontal segment (Option C): Incorrect — this part is near the tympanic cavity, but chorda tympani arises lower down.

questions.text:
Choose the correct set of statements regarding the course of the facial nerve

1) The extracranial part of facial nerve lies lateral to retromandibular vein

2) Facial nerve exits the skull via stylomastoid foramen

3) Greater petrosal nerve is a branch of facial nerve after the formation of geniculate ganglion

4) The facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

Origin:

The facial nerve arises from the pons, a part of the brainstem, at the pontomedullary junction.

 

Pathway:

  • After its origin, the facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). (Statement 4)
  • It then travels through the facial canal within the temporal bone.

 

Key Structures Along Its Course

Geniculate Ganglion:

Located within the facial canal, this is a sensory ganglion where the nerve fibers for taste (from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue) and some general sensory fibers synapse.

 

Branches within the Facial Canal:

  • Greater Petrosal Nerve: Arises from the geniculate ganglion, carrying parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland and nasal mucosa. (Statement 3)
  • Chorda Tympani: This branch arises after the geniculate ganglion and carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.

 

Exit from the Skull

Stylomastoid Foramen:

The facial nerve exits the skull here, located between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone.(Statement 2)

 

Extracranial part of facial nerve:

Entry into Parotid Gland
  • Main trunk enters on the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland.

Division of Nerve
  • Divides within the gland, behind and superficial to the retromandibular vein (Statement 1) and external carotid artery (ECA).

Temporofacial vs. Cervicofacial Trunks
  • Temporofacial trunk: Contains more axons but fewer fascicles.
  • Cervicofacial trunk: Contains more fascicles but fewer axons.

Formation of Parotid Plexus
  • The trunks branch further to form the parotid plexus (pes anserinus) from which the terminal branches arise.

Terminal Branches
  • Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female known hypertensive presented with sudden onset weakness over the left half of her body. On examination, her face was deviated to one side associated with slurring of speech. The doctor asks the intern to perform a facial nerve examination. Which among the following statements is correct regarding the most likely intratemporal segment of the nerve involved?

choices.text: Only segment of the facial nerve that lacks anastomosing cascades
Bill’s bar is related to this segment
Shortest and widest segment of facial nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) only segment of the facial nerve that lacks anastomosing cascades

 

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute ischaemic stroke. Labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is most prone to ischaemia.

 

Intratemporal Facial nerve:

Extends from Internal acoustic meatus (IAM) to stylomastoid foramen. Further divided into,

Meatal segment
  • 8-10mm length, within IAM
  • Bill’s bar is a bony landmark related to the Meatal segment of facial nerve (Option C)

Labyrinthine segment
  • 4mm length, from fundus of meatus to geniculate ganglion
  • Shortest and narrowest segment (Option D)
  • Most prone segment to compression (narrowest) and ischaemia due to lack of anastomosing arterial cascades.(Option B)
  • Ends at 1st genu.

Tympanic (horizontal) segment
  • 11mm length, from geniculate ganglion to just above the pyramidal eminence.
  • Most common site of dehiscence of temporal bone (facial canal)
  • Lies above oval window and below lateral semicircular canal

Mastoid (vertical) segment
  • 13mm length,from the pyramid to the stylomastoid foramen
  • Arises from 2nd genu.
  • Most common segment to be injured in mastoid surgery

Contains epineurial and perineurial sheaths (Option A): Proximal segments i.e Meatal, Labyrinthine and Horizontal segments lack Epineurial and Perineurial sheaths.

Topodiagnostic tests of Facial nerve:

Test

Nerve Branch

Assessment/Outcome

Schirmer’s Test

Greater (superficial) petrosal nerve
  • A unilateral decrease in tear production (>75%) (Option B) or
  • Bilateral reduction (less than 10 mm in both eyes after 5 minutes).

Stapedial Reflex

Nerve to stapedius muscle
  • Reflex is either present or absent

Electro- gustometry

Chorda tympani
  • The taste threshold is compared between the two sides to detect abnormalities

Salivary Flow Testing

Chorda tympani
  • A 25% reduction in salivary flow is considered abnormal

questions.text: Choose the correct course of the intracranial part of the facial nerve.

choices.text: VIIth nerve nucleus→pontomedullary junction→posterior cranial fossa→internal acoustic meatus
Internal acoustic meatus→VIIth nerve nucleus→posterior cranial fossa→pontomedullary junction
Posterior cranial fossa→internal acoustic meatus→pontomedullary junction→VIIth nerve nucleus
Pontomedullary junction→VIIth nerve nucleus→internal acoustic meatus→posterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) VIIth nerve nucleus→pontomedullary junction→posterior cranial fossa→internal acoustic meatus

 

Explanation:

  • Intracranial part of facial nerve - part of the facial nerve till it reaches the internal acoustic meatus
  • The course of the intracranial part of the facial nerve:

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient experiences sudden right-sided facial drooping and weakness in the left arm and leg following a stroke. The stroke is in the ventral part of the pons (basis pontis). Infranuclear fascicular fibers of cranial nerve VII (CN VII) ipsilaterally and the corticospinal tract contralaterally are affected. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Millard-Gubler Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Millard-Gubler Syndrome (MGS)

  • Caused by a lesion in the ventral part of the pons (basis pontis)
  • The lesion involves the infranuclear fascicular fibers of cranial nerve VII (CN VII) ipsilaterally and the corticospinal tract contralaterally.
  • Results in:
    • Ipsilateral peripheral facial paralysis.
    • Contralateral hemiplegia.
  • Cranial nerve VI (CN VI) involvement sometimes

 

Foville syndrome (Option A): Caused by a lesion in pons

  • Ipsilateral facial palsy
  • Horizontal gaze palsy
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome
  • Loss of hearing
  • Facial pain or temperature sensation
  • Contralateral loss of vibration, fine touch, and proprioception

 

Wallenberg syndrome (Option B): Caused by a lesion in brainstem

  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Dizziness or vertigo
  • Problems with balance and walking
  • Involuntary eye movements (nystagmus)
  • Loss of pain or temperature sensation on one side of the body
  • Hoarseness
  • Loss of taste
  • Facial pain

 

Weber syndrome (Option D): Caused by a lesion in midbrain

  • Drooping eyelid
  • Double vision
  • Partial or complete weakness in the arm and leg on contralateral side of the body
  • Pupils may be dilated and unresponsive if both upper and middle midbrain are affected
  • Contralateral ataxia may be present
  • There may be a parkinsonian type of rigidity
